Title: Mapping the Impact of Gut Microbiota on Brain and Behaviour through the Lens of GABA

Abstract:

This interdisciplinary project aims to elucidate the impact of gut microbiota on brain and behaviour, with a specific focus on the neurotransmitter GABA. Despite the significant genetic similarity between humans (99% identical), individual differences in gut bacteria composition can have a profound impact (1% difference). The gut microbiome is composed of distinct bacteria (40-90% different from human cells), with a 1:1 bacteria-to-human cell ratio and a 10:1 bacteria-to-human DNA ratio. While the influence of gut-produced neurotransmitters like GABA and serotonin on brain and behaviour remains a significant knowledge gap, our biochemically informed approach will investigate the modulation of brain GABA levels and GABA-ergic task performance by gut bacteria in human adults using Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy.

The project consists of two work packages: (1) investigating the relationship between gut bacteria and brain GABA levels, and (2) testing the impact of ingested GABA-producing bacteria on brain and behaviour over four weeks using a custom-made probiotic. By integrating psychology, neuroscience, and gut microbiology, this project seeks to understand how gut bacteria and probiotics influence brain GABA levels and function, ultimately shedding light on individual differences in human behaviour and brain function. Our research has the potential to inform novel therapeutic strategies for neurological and psychiatric disorders.

Title: Mapping the Impact of Gut Microbiota on Brain and Behaviour through the Lens of GABA

The intricate relationship between the gut microbiota and the brain remains poorly understood, particularly in regards to the impact of gut-produced neurotransmitters on brain function and behaviour. This project aims to fill this knowledge gap by investigating the role of gut bacteria in modulating brain GABA levels and GABA-ergic task performance. Building on the biochemical understanding of gut-brain interactions, we will employ a multidisciplinary approach, combining psychology, neuroscience, and gut microbiology to explore the complex relationships between gut bacteria, brain GABA, and behaviour.

Our research will involve two interconnected work packages. First, we will investigate how gut bacteria modulate brain GABA levels and GABA-ergic task performance in human adults using Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy. Second, we will test the impact of ingesting custom-made probiotics containing GABA-producing bacteria on brain and behaviour over a four-week period. By elucidating the mechanisms underlying the gut-brain axis, this project aims to understand how individual differences in gut microbiota contribute to variations in human behaviour and brain function. Our findings will have significant implications for the development of novel probiotic-based interventions targeting brain GABA function and behaviour.
